title: Do you think money is everything? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, but that differs person to person. Money is entitled to a value. It has a value and you can't really take it away. That's something people need to understand. Generally, people think that giving importance to money or value is a sign of greediness and so on. We judge people by the way they behave for money. We fear telling out loud, about money's value as people might make assumptions. But it's all fake. There isn't a soul who does not care about money. We all yearn for things. We all fill in our basic desires using cash. So we can't really differentiate people or classify them. I remember people pointing out loud that they believe money is absolutely nothing in life. Note: it has its value. The outfit we wear and the food we consume and so on, name it- is bought out of money. Whoever claims that money is not at all important, in order to seem less selfish, is actually filled with pride and is attention-seeking. We do need money. How else would you pay for food? How else would you get shelter? If you get shelter from someone else- do remember that they too, are paying for the shelter. Whatever you get has something to do with money. There are several kinds of joy. Some that money can buy and some that money cannot buy. Can't really fuss much about it. You really want a good, cozy house to live in? You need money. Good food to enjoy with your spouse? Money. Travel around the world? Money. And at the same time, money won't bring back the dead or someone who wishes not to be in your life. There are things you can buy and things you cannot buy. Your joy depends on that. And you know what? There is nothing wrong with yearning for money. There is nothing wrong with money at all and I realise that as I write this. Why isn't there anything wrong? Because money isn't illegal. You work hard, use your effort and your intelligence to get paid. You do trade something, so the cash in hand belongs to you. It belongs to you, entirely. However, it goes off limits when people go overboard with the things they can do with money. And money could destroy someone. Money could fill a person with greed and cover up everything. That's where you've got humanity fighting. We need to face the truth and accept it: Money is essential to survive. Yet, money shouldn't control us. It shouldn't take over us- it has its importance. Money has its value. You leave it where it belongs… Its importance, however; depends on you.

Yes. Okay, okay. Hear me out, before you all start bashing the life out of me: Money isn’t be all, end all. However, money is a pretty huge chunk of everything. Money dictates everything. It decides if whether or not you get to eat dinner tonight. Or if you’re sleeping with two blankets because you can’t afford the heater in your house. People like to say that money can’t buy love and friendship. But every person you’ve ever known, befriended or became enemies with is an indirect byproduct of money. Money starts relationships.  You meet eyes with this girl at the bar and think she’s drop-dead gorgeous. Why? Is it her perfectly straight, white smile? On average, braces can cost from $5,000-6,000. Is it that cute t-shirt? That was $32 from Urban Outfitters. Is it the intoxicating smell of her hair? The smell of that coconut shampoo you like so much? The fact she can afford $104 for her own electricity and water bills so she can shower is so hot. People don’t realize that money is on everything. It’s the clothes you wear. What phone you have. The computer you type on. The food you eat. The school you go to- if you even went to school at all! Money dictates everything. Your class of education, your quality of living, the type of people you’re surrounded with. The exact words you speak. Your opinions. Your beliefs. It’s all the byproduct of money. It’s easy to be ignorant and preach how: Oh, money is meaningless! Money means nothing! Only shallow people care about such trivial things! But it’s not true. Money posses an immeasurable amount power. It destroys lives. It makes new ones. I think money is everything. But just because it’s everything, doesn’t mean you should revolve your whole life around it. You don’t need money to be happy. You don’t need it to find love. You don’t need it to find fulfillment in life. But money is everywhere, and it’s important to remember that.

“Havin' money's not everything, not havin' it is.” This is a lyric from Kanye West’s song Good Life that immediately came to my mind. For me, money isn’t everything, but I know how it can make life shitty without it. I remember living in a homeless shelter. I would walk past stores and see people buying food. I could only look at the food. I didn’t have the money to afford to eat. It completely sucked being in that situation. Now, I have money in my pocket. I can eat at any place that I choose. I recently went to a smoothie shop. I ordered a smoothie and vegan chocolate chip cookie. It felt great being able to waste almost $8 bucks on these items and tip $1. Later on, I went to a southern cuisine restaurant that is buzzing on social media due to the fact it’s owned by a famous person from a reality show. I ate their fried chicken meal with macaroni and cheese, collard greens, and Kandi yams. I only drank water. The meal ended up costing $20 bucks and $4 for the tip. In both instances, it felt absolutely wonderful being able to have money. I didn’t have to be the person looking at other people consuming food and wondering exactly how it tasted. Money gave me access to solving this riddle. Money is simply a tool that can open doors. It keeps my smartphone on. It allows me to purchase a seat on the bus to go to Nashville next month. It buys my shoes, deodorant, dish washing soap, lotion, toothpaste, medication, U.S. Passport, Atlanta Dream season tickets, and so many other necessary and not so necessary items. I’ve tried to use money to replace love and friendship. I discovered that it cannot make someone love you or care about you. It won’t prevent you from feeling loneliness. Spending money on prostitutes only lead to emptiness for me. There’s nothing better than being with someone that you don’t have to pay to be in your life. I’m not just talking about sex workers. I’m applying that to family and friends. You want people in your life that love and appreciate you for you. You don’t want them in your life simply for your things. I know what it feels like to live with and without money. I learned that living with money makes your life easier. You don’t worry as much about how you are going to pay for something. If you need it, you simply go and get it. I remember when I would lose money in my pockets and find it weeks later. In fact, I lost a $20 bill in my pocket. I happened to be at the gas station when I discovered it. The gas station attendant looked at me and said, “You didn’t even know you had that money in your pocket. I can tell by the way you were puzzled to see it. You must lose money and forget about it all of the time. I wish I had that problem.” I could only smile and agree with him. I made $700 per week after taxes. I was a single guy without a care in the world. I also know what it feels like to live without money. I had to learn how to adapt to my circumstances in the men’s shelter. I quickly began to talk to the men and find out what they did to eat. I discovered many places that fed homeless people for free. In addition, on the weekends, I would work in the shelter’s kitchen and eat really well. I learned how to get around Atlanta on the transportation system. I discovered how to keep my clothes clean. I still have these skills. I am bipolar. I sometimes experience extreme mania and extreme depression. In addition, this is often coupled with anxiety, panic attacks, self hatred, self love, and grandiose opinions of myself. I lack control over these mood swings. There isn’t any amount of money that would take this mental health condition away from me. If I could buy it away, I would. However, I know that isn’t a reality. I would love to have a close relationship with my family. Unfortunately, I do not believe that my family wants to understand me. They simply want me to be what they want me to be. I will never meet their expectations. But family is definitely more than money. If you have it, hold on to it and cherish it. I’ve never been the type of person to have true friends in real life. I have plenty of associates, but I’ve never had close friendships with people. I have family members that have really awesome friendships with people from high school and university. I don’t have this in my life. I definitely know friendship is way more important than money.

“Money has never made man happy, nor will it; there is nothing in its nature to produce happiness. The more of it one has the more one wants.”­ – Benjamin Franklin Money gives you freedom and choices. You can decide where and how you want to live when you have a good income or financial resources. On the other hand, when you do not have much money, choice may be something that you cannot afford. The choices available to you may not really be choices at all. While true that “money can’t buy happiness”, it at least provides some security. Being poor is never something that one strives to attain. Many people who become extremely wealthy often grow up in poor households, which strengthens their resolve to never again relive the experience. “You aren't wealthy until you have something money can't buy” LoveMoney can buy lust, attraction and power…but it can’t buy love. This is because love is something intimate; something heartfelt; something mysterious. Money is none of these things. Money is simply a method of exchange – no more and no less. It’s used to pay for a product or a service; its convenience, comfort, and luxury – none of which typify what human beings truly need. Many of us find this lesson out the hard way. We accumulate more, only to feel emptier. This is because we are raised in a culture that glamorizes wealth; which, in effect, leads to misconceptions and false beliefs. TimeEach passing minute is time that you will never get back; you are one minute closer to dying. This is not meant to be morbid or depressing, but truthful. Our life starts to fade away from the moment we are born. Despite all of the scientific and medical advances, there exists no practical way to significantly extend life. The extremely wealthy have spent countless amounts of money in the vain attempt to extend their lives only to find out that they die around the same age as everyone else. No amount of money will be able to turn the clocks back. We must simply take life in, moment-by-moment, while experiencing it to the fullest. PeaceThe cultivation of your thoughts is the only thing that will ever bring you true peace. One aspect of this is accepting when bad things happen and turning it into a positive experience. Look at the countless amounts of money that governments and individuals have spent in the name of “peace”. These vast sums have never been able to come close to what we would define as “peaceful”. More importantly, your inner peace does not depend on the ‘balance’ section of your bank statement. It’s how you train your mind, set expectations, and define what inner peace truly means to you. TalentThe gifts and abilities that you possess in your mind and body are priceless. While money can certain help develop a talent, it will never be able to purchase a talent or skill. Aside from innate talent, there is the ability to learn a skill or talent; this will never be able to be purchased with any amount of money. The mental processes and dexterity of the mind and body will never be purchasable…they are invaluable. HealthWhile certainly true that money can purchase healthcare and medicine, it cannot replace natural health once it’s gone. At the same time, activities like exercise, preventative medicine, and natural self-care costs little to nothing. It’s almost depressing to see celebrities spend outrageous amounts of money in the vain attempt to keep their “natural beauty”. First off, aging is natural beauty; wrinkling is natural beauty; gray hair is natural beauty. On the other hand, surgical procedures that implant plastic and other medicinal substances into the body? This is not at all natural. True friendsPossessing money may certainly attract people who want to be friends, but it doesn’t guarantee true friendship. Most true friends love one another…and what did we discuss about money and love? The same concept applies here. True and lasting friends are the ones there during the ‘boom’ and are still there during the ‘bust’. Money and possessions don’t matter to true friends…your person matters. KnowledgeThe information that you accumulate, the elements of your intellect, and the ways that you exhibit wisdom can never be bought. Have you ever wondered why some of the wealthiest people seem to act in the most asinine ways? This is because money or something else has influenced their thought processes. Some wealthy people have stated how money makes them feel ‘invincible’, and as a result have made some truly bad decisions. So it’s not only the acquisition of this knowledge that makes it invaluable, it’s the practical application of this knowledge…neither of which money can buy.

Everything? No. Important? A lot more than I originally thought it was. My father made and still makes a very decent salary. However, my parents relationship was… rocky. In fact, they haven’t lived under the same roof for any extended period of time in over a decade. This, despite the fact that they’re still married, act as a couple, and had my youngest sister long after they weren’t living together anymore. Trust me, as strange as it sounds, it works better for everyone. During the time period that they did live together, the fighting was a constant. And very often, it seemed to center on money. Whether there was enough of it. Whether my father should take that newer more prestigious job that was located on the other side of the country. Whether or not we were all appreciative enough of everything that was being sacrificed for us in the interest of earning more etc. So, by the time I was a teenager, I was pretty positive that I hated money. We definitely had it, and we were all definitely miserable. Furthermore, never having really known anything other than a materially comfortable existence, I couldn’t appreciate exactly how large a role money had played in it. So, I took the fairly reactive stance that I would never chase it. I deliberately refused to pick a major in college based on future earning potential, I refused to put any value on creature comforts, and I had the upmost contempt for anyone who did. However, as I have matured slightly, I find myself far more appreciative of the reasons some people do put a high value on money and on the act of acquiring it. Having it as child afforded me some incredibly positive life experiences. I got to see more of the world by the time I was ten, than some people do in an entire lifetime. I got to travel the country. I got to join clubs and play sports. I had access to up to date technology. I picked college based on where I wanted to go with the expectation that the vast majority of it would be paid for. However, as an adult, my job is, and has been in some form or another since I joined the workforce, to work with adolescents who come from families that don’t really have much of anything in the way of financial stability. It’s opened my eyes to a lot, and has caused me to reassess a lot of my own hang ups. Money, at least in society as it functions now, is a necessary tool. Not having enough of it is highly detrimental. Detrimental, in ways that it is hard to fathom for people who have always been accustomed to it’s presence. When is enough of it enough? Well, I don’t know, and I guess it varies. For my father, who grew up in abject poverty, there can never be enough. For me? I guess it falls somewhere in the middle. Except that my middle is skewed, by having been raised in such a way as to expect that it would always be there. So, while money isn’t everything in the sense that it doesn’t magically create happiness for those who have it, it does afford a degree of stability, safety, and protection from some of the more dangerous aspects of life, that can be invaluable in terms of having the time/ability to find exactly what it is that does bring fulfillment and satisfaction. And like most things I suppose, it’s about finding a balance. At any rate, it makes me laugh now to realize that so much of my teenaged existential angst over money, was in fact only made possible because my family had enough of it.

Actually, Yes. Life is all about money.  You are born and you are put up in school. Not because you are meant to learn, gain new experiences and become a happy, intelligent and better human being but because one day you can find a good job and bring in some money. People (mostly) compare your success with others based on your bank balance - how much money you make through your business or job. More money means more success Mostly, people do not see how much valuable your work is to the society or how much it is contributing for the welfare of others. If you are rich and wealthy it means you are successful in the eyes of many. Undoubtedly! I tell you a story. When I was quite young, my uncle was talking about his friend, let’s call him Sam. “Sam was a person who bothered least about the money.He was humorous, entertaining and knew how to make people around him feel happy. He do not work but he keeps good relationship with people. When he got married and had children, he used to take his wife and young children to various places and they have visited a number of places in the entire country. Though the wife was worried because they did not have enough money to sustain children and once sold her jewellery to pay the bills and fees, he did not bother about going out and finding a job. His habits were just the same and the wife then started working to take care of the family and keep up with the expenses. He believed in god and always lived a happy life not caring about money. That is the reason for his success.” I asked: What, I do not get it? How this makes him successful when the family is facing financial problems? Uncle said: He knew his father saved a lot of money which he will get when the father will die. End of story. See how money came into picture in the life of a person who just do not care about making money. There is no escape from the fact that we all need money and no matter what it will always be important. Money is created by us so that we can use it to buy goods and services necessary to sustain our life. You need money to get food, pay bills, buy things for your loved ones, educate your children and fulfill other necessities. Greed is bad but making money for your necessities isn’t. If you have enough money that you can provide yourself and your family a happy life then you should relax for a moment, give time to your loved ones and feel the happiness by spending time with them.  I personally believe that being wealthy is important but it is also very important how you make money and how your actions/work contribute to the welfare of people, nation and environment. Your life is a success if you are wealthy, have a happy family and your work benefits the world. If you are wealthy, you should work hard and contribute to the welfare of those who need your help or work to spread some happiness and smile. Even if you are not wealthy and living an average life, your life is a success if you are able to live happily with your family because deep inside we all know love is what makes the life worth living. I hope this enlightens!

Hell no. Life is about finding true happiness. Happiness can only come from within. It doesn’t come from money or anything material. Why? If you rely on money for your happiness, then you fall into an endless cycle of frustration. What cycle? The cycle of thinking “I’ll be happy if I get X,” then getting X, not being satisfied, then thinking “I’ll be happy if I get Y,” then getting Y, and then keeping on with that same cycle of frustration. Unfortunately this is what we’ve been led to believe - that chasing after money and after temporary things will bring us fulfillment. But it doesn’t. In America people are more depressed and anxious than ever, even though we have so much. That’s because the more you have, the more you want, and the harder it is to find true happiness and contentment.How does one achieve happiness then? Have you ever searched all over the place for something, only to realize that you’ve had it within you all along. Happiness is like that. Rather than trying to fulfill every desire that comes to our minds, we can instead be content with what we currently have. That’s because trying to fulfill each and every desire we have is an endless process that only leads to frustration because the more we try to satisfy our desires, the more desires we end up having. And we can never be happy if we are always in a state of desiring something because as long as we desire something, we can never achieve peace in the current moment.The way to achieve this state of contentment is through spirituality. There’s a reason every major culture has had a component of spirituality to it. We’re spiritual beings at our core. Through spirituality, we reconnect to our original source (The Supreme, God, Allah, Jehovah, Krishna, etc.). By doing so, we begin to experience everlasting, ever-increasing bliss. Through this bliss we can become fully happy and content. We become unconditionally happy meaning that we’re happy all the time despite other circumstances in our life. You won’t have to search out for happiness anymore. You’ll always have it with you instead. Look how happy he is. Proof that you don’t need much to be happy. That being said, money is nice in the sense that it affords us our basic necessities. After that, the path of inner contentment will always bring more happiness than the path of greed and materialism. If you want to do some more reading on this topic, I’d also recommend this article

Not in the slightest, of course I'd like to be comfortable to pay bills on time, food etc. Money does not make the person, money makes things far more complex. Money (Especially at death) brings out the true dark nature of the real person hiding behind the mask. Money stays here when your dead, money won't save you from the same ending destined for all of our journeys. Money places emphasis on status, that someone at the top is somehow better than someone from poor socionomic backgrounds. Money doesn't define the person, integrity defines the person. Money sounds nice, but it doesn't make people do nice things overall. Why are the wealthy experiencing the same mental health concerns as everyone else? Because we are just evolved monkeys who decided this paper, or this metal has currency. I ADDED THE LAST PART, YOU DON'T HAVE TO CONTINUE READING, BUT PERHAPS YOU'D LET ME RANT FOR A SHOT MOMENT OF TIME TO RAISE A HOPEFULLY GENUINE POINT. HOW I HAD TO LOSE ALL TO BE FILTHY RICH (With enlightenment and wisdom I wish I knew sooner) 👇👇👇👇👇 Earlier this year I lost everything… Literally everything but the cloths I own & a few sentimental random items etc. I live in a friend's dining room, declared bankruptcy, all from a insidious addiction. But I must say, it took losing my possessions, selling my furniture, car, computer, anything of value. Granted it at the time was for substance that I grapple with. However it's losing everything I used to hold dear, having a nice car, good stereo, decent computer, new furniture etc. It sent me through a whirlwind of emotions. Depression, loss, suicidal ideation etc. But once the initial phase moved past I actually learnt… I'm no longer held down by pointless possessions, my car didn't define who I was, my computer wasn't a part of my personality anyone gave a shit about. Anyone who defined me by the way I dress is not someone I want in my life. Well not to dress like a total slob lol. Casual and loathe formal attire. Comfortable but smart, I don't fit any status, no name brands advertised. I wish to be judged based on me, my interactions, my creativity, my wishes to help others as I once sorely needed. Not material positions that plague my mind, needing the best, for whom? Everything I have is enough, and I'm comfortable. Adding more doesn't make better, grander, change who I truly am. Stripped naked and venerable for all to tear apart, I am exactly like you, colour might be different, origins might not match yours, status most likely not poignant like desired ones by others. I am man, human, bleed, cry, laugh, breath, my kidneys can replace yours if you were ill, I am not of my possessions, I hold dear the things that matter. It took losing it all to gain so much more than I ever dreamt. I gained control over my addiction, completed rehab, enrolled to study & have a fresh start. No concerns for status, what I do or don't have. Having nothing is so liberating, I've never felt so free. My phone is 3 years old & I still love it. The old status seeking me would upgrade, why? Because I have the latest crap that does the same as the last crap. But now I can take photos of my crap in an even better quality HD camera. I realised what I do have works perfectly for my immediate needs. Will having more make me better than I hope to be? Will having status symbols make people see I am empathetic and wish to help those suffering the way I once did? Drugs took it all away, but it also gave me a complete fresh start. Not many people are lucky for a second chance. So no, money is no concern to me whatsoever. My desire to help and educate those who struggle is considerably stronger than having some crap to feel better, or impress some selfish arsehole who I don't respect. You don't have to go extremes like I, but we all have the same innate ability to see if we take the blinders off and asses the situation. Will money make you better? Solve your problems? Maybe at the start, but there will be far worse issues around the corner that one can't just chuck money at to go away. Cancer doesn't take a cheque, Alzheimer's disease doesn't take PayWave, schizophrenia doesn't do PayPal, Parkinson's disease doesn't understand Interbank transfers… Life can be so much more wholesome when one loses the lust for money, status & admiration. Life is full of free things, stars at night, sunset in summer, aurora borealis, the serenity of life deep in a forrest, the secluded deserts, raging rivers, majestic oceans. The animal life that surrounds us. Money can't buy that, infact money is actively destroying that as we speak. Money, greed, power, status…? Do you really want to be apart of that mean machine? What is left after we've ravaged our home to leave for our successors? An empty wasteland derived from greed. Well not for me at least… Stay safe all, be Covid19 smart and look after your mental health ✌️

Definitely not about my life. As a child I wondered why we are here. I was four years old and knew there was no Santa. I got interested in bible stories and finally went to a Catholic School (my mom laughed when I wanted to go as she said they were strict, she didn’t go to church, either did my dad). I got baptized when I was twelve and it was the happiest day of my life. Well, much happened to me, and I did get taken advantage of in many ways. It’s too tragic to write about, but ended up marrying the wrong person for safety. I passed up many wealthy men who wanted to marry me, and some days I’m sorry I didn’t do that. I went away from the church for years, ended up marrying three times and being left twice. The problem with me and money is that I have been abandoned a couple of times, and found out I had to depend on myself. So, God was good to me in that my mom left me her house and some savings. I studied the stock market as I know she didn’t believe in it. I would die if I wasted her hard-earned money. Since I was careful, I didn’t lose the money, I made a lot more and saved instead of spending. That’s why I write articles to young people telling them to save because we never know what’s going to happen. As dad used to say “pay yourself first.” which he meant try to save at least ten percent of everything you get. Now, money seemed to be the most important thing to my first husband who left me when our business went down. He married a wealthy woman. The bad part of it is splitting the children. They would stay with me and then with “them,” and “them” had lotsa money. It gets to people no matter what they say…gold. “They” had a sign in their house which said “he who has the gold has the rule.” And, she was supposed to be big in the Episcopal church. I think it gets to my girls at times. However, the elder girl made all of her big money herself! I’m proud of that, but, it can get to you to make a lot of money, also. It seems when people get richer they want more and more. So, I feel sorry for those who put money first, and not God. It is against the First Commandment “Put the Lord, thy God, above all.” My girls do believe in God, but one not sure about Jesus. I’m hurt quite often when I find them choosing to be at “their parent’s” functions instead of with me. After all, “they” have very exciting lives. I’ve had several different lifestyles, and sometimes I look back to my convent school where we wore uniforms, no one knew how much the other families had, and all studied quite a bit, all girls schools, no dating, no fooling around, just church, school, and a little recreation, then more study and sleep in a dorm. We always had nuns looking after us. At the time, we couldn’t wait to get out, but now I would like to be back there! Sometimes, we do not know when we have it good. I went on to be a nerd in high school at first, then learned the ways of the world of makeup, clothes, mannerisms, and won Homecoming Queen. I found out all is “image.” People fall for image. Later, I found out there’s such a thing as being “too popular.” Long story, but passed up the good guys and ended up living a bad guy. Came to Dallas to start over, but married someone from the hotel… If you marry, be sure to do what I was told to do and I didn’t. Marry someone with the same religion or the same goals in life, the same beliefs, and discuss the future. People are on their best behavior when dating. Of course nowadays, people don't seem to bother to get married. I think that’s the trouble with the world now, no families. We are leaning towards a culture of globalization and humanism. That’s another discussion. This is about “is money all there is?” Life should be about love of God, family and country. There was a recent poll and the happiest people are those who are married, with family and love each other. Not the richest.

Go back 70,000 years. All creatures were equally balanced on earth with human races being with more cerebrum. What was life all about? Passing on genes to keep species alive and thrive. All creatures had the same purpose: survival and growth of species. Then humans making great use of cerebrum succeed in the purpose increasing number exponentially. Survival became easier and now humans thrived. Humans grew social. Society grew. The problem of survival went behind the curtains. Human life became complex than before. New problems of daily life started arising which were not entirely natural. Instances: Now humans didn’t hunt so needed food, so, came food sellers.Better clothes, more clothes, to this end, came cloth makers.Ornaments became part of life, therefore, came ornament makers.Need to build bigger houses, to help, came laborers.Protection from invading groups needed specialized weapons, there were weapon makers.No one had all, came traders.To solve the problems, solutions were created and so were many solution creators. Solutions became valuable so needed value in return. Early forms of Money came up to help in exchange of solution to the problem. Complexity grew. Solutions grew. Now trades of solutions for problems increased exponentially as did complexity. Money made this trading easier. Money became a primary facilitator of solutions to almost all problems. Now it seems money is a need for everything. So is life all about money? Go back to the time before life became complex. What was life all about? Passing on genes to continuation human life. Now it's not a problem as we are in plenty. We have grown out of the survival problem. But remove all complexities of life. It becomes simple like 70,000 years ago. A family, friends living and fighting for survival to ensure their lineage goes on and on. Today humanity has so many problems there are so many purposes (to solve these problems). But at the heart of everything is survival of species. Ask Sentinels of Andaman. They want their lineage to live on and on. Life is all about continuation of human life generation after generation. All others are ancillary to the continuation of humans.

It really depends on an individual. Most individuals don’t care about the kind of life they live. They really just look for people around them, see how they eat, drink, party in teenage, marry, beget kids, get jobs during mid-age and spend time with grandkids or visiting churches when old. Seeing this, they create a template for themselves and build their life using their template. If you are that person who lives a templatized life, then money is not that important for you. One can get most of the things promised by a templatized life without really putting money or self-improvement as the focus for ones life. Such people are also the ones who just don’t see the point in earning more money than what’s sufficient or are generally disparaging of those who work hard or take risks to earn more money. However, if you find no happiness or meaning in the templatized life, then money is definitely the most important thing for you. I’d call such a person a “free soul”. The true value of money lies in this fact: Money essentially buys freedom and time. A free soul needs time and freedom to do more than what the templatized life promises. Free souls are not happy being the best shoulder to cry on or the best employee of the week. Free souls want to make a dent in the universe. They want to explore the limits of their potential. They want to wake up in the lap of Himalayas, listening to ancient monks chanting and not wake up to an alarm reminding them that they have a report to submit. They want to work crazy hours in a lab looking for that genetic loophole which might save lives of a million cancer-stricken patients, and not spend time binge-watching shows on Netflix. With time and freedom that money gets a free soul, he or she can achieve true happiness that he or she seeks. Money is also the way by which a free soul can justify his or her inability to enjoy what others enjoy from a templatized life and need for special wants from life. A free soul without money to buy time and freedom is generally sad and ridiculed by others for not following the template. But money ensures that they become ridicule-proof and shows a mirror to others who are content with the sheer ordinariness of what they expect or want from life. Most importantly, a free soul will never use money on materialistic objectives. For them, the value of money lies in the freedom and time it buys, and not the hookers or lamborghinis that can be bought.

That is one of the easiest questions to answer: Think about two possible lives, one in which you are rich but depressed, and one in which you are poor but incredibly happy with your life. Which life would you rather have?  If you have suffered from Depression before, you will pick that second one without a second thought! But even if you haven’t, just based on the fact that you would be happy in that second life, what do you really have to lose? Let’s expand that thought just a little bit more and look at two different possible lives: Life #1: You are incredibly rich AND happy, but you do not feel fulfilled. You are doing a lot of enjoyable things but you do not feel like your life has much meaning as it brought no value to the world. Life #2: You are incredibly broke but you have given value to the world. You feel as though your passion/mission that you set yourself has brought some lasting change with it. Which life would you rather have? Understand that it’s not that easy to say what life is all about, as it’s not that black and white. Life is a huge mess of things, and of course money is in there somewhere too.  Money does play a big role, but if you look at rich people you will find the same things you find with poor people. You will find people who are happy, depressed, excited, and people who are bored out of their minds. You will find those that care for others and those that abuse others. And you will find people that think their life is worthless and people that work harder than any poorer person because they have a mission, passion or obsession they work towards. In this way, I would say life is definitely not all about money. Life is about whatever you make it about! For some people life is all about their family, for others about their achievement, and for others still about the experiences they make. Money is only a means to an end, nothing more.  It will not fulfill you, will not bring you happiness, and will not do anything at all on its own. But, depending on how you use it, it can make everything a lot easier. With money you can have a bigger impact on the world, support your family easier and create more options to be happy; however, whether or not you use it for that still depends on you!

No. Life is not all about money. Life cannot be all about a certain ‘thing’. This is because life is essentially empty and meaningless. We all fill it with meanings. We have no choice. Again these meanings are not absolute. They are arbitrary. Each one of us interprets it in ways unique to him or her. And this interpretation comes from Mankind’s greatest invention-language. Interpretations, by definition, can never match the reality. In a way they are a story - a concoction, a creation weaved out of words. Each story sounds real and true to his/her author! My life would have been this and that had I had enough money at this or that phase of my life…..and conversations like these are just stories, albeit real for their authors. Since childhood we are subjected to many events. They impact us in varying degrees. Stories get created around these events and they make us who we are. ‘Only if I had gone to an English medium school, I would have gone places in my career’ , ‘ If I had a rich father, I wouldn’t have languished in this rotten job-I would have been a businessman’ …… are all stories. We have stories about money also - stories inexorably intertwined with the events from our past. Lack of money, impoverishment, stagnation, crime etc is a story at one end of the gamut and too much money, profligacy, moral corruption, alienation is the story at the other end. All these stories are dis-empowering. The more empowering story would be: money is a tool invented by mankind to facilitate economic affairs. You need money for a lot of things. But good to remember to not lose things money can’t buy. All precious (non-material) things in life are above money - things such as time, love, peace of mind, loyalty, dedication, caring children, willingness to die for the country, wisdom etc . We are very naive to believe having bought, say ‘A’ by buying that within which ‘A’ resides. We buy mansions for earning a place among the elites. We buy vacation to a serene island in order to ‘experience’ peace of mind. We buy expensive Art in order to become someone who understands art. We buy our kids admissions to elite schools and colleges in order to buy wisdom. Why do we run after these things if life is empty and meaningless ? Ultimately what gets us immense sense of fulfillment? Is it money? No. It’s appreciation. We all want appreciation. And lots of it. Money, power, fame all are gateways to appreciation, for most of us. Therefore, we chase them until our lives are spent and become what they are in the first place - empty and meaningless !

That differs from person to person. For me relations and having fun( in a good way) is important. So think!!! What will make you happy??? Let me tell you a story. There was a tribe in africa. People of that tribe was happy with what they have and never complained. They valued relations and even didn’t know the existence of money. They possessed many riches like natural gold, diamonds, spices etc.They are happy with what they have and was leading a peaceful life. One day a civilized man ( a scientist ) encountered them while carrying on some research. He find them amusing, illiterate. He pitied and decided to educate them for their better growth. He approached them and said that he will help them. He educated them about various aspects like economy, management and so on. He took leave from them for continuing his research work and promised that he will revisit them after a year. Time passed and to fulfil his promise, the scientist returned to village. He was depressed to find the people in sorrow and dismay, who once were filled with extreme joy. He asked them to explain the reason for their sorrow. They used to live happily when once they didn’t even know the existence of money. They used to share whatever they have and spent the remaining time with their loved ones. When the scientist taught them about money , knowledge and other things , they became greedy. They forgot the essence of the life and wasted their time in acquiring useless things . Moral: Its not about money , power or anything!!! The point is “ARE YOU HAPPY WITH WHAT YOU HAVE?” If your happiness lies in money, then go after it. If it lies in the luxuries , relations , travelling….. It may be anything. Go after it. “You’ll be the happiest man if YOU DON’T HAVE ANY REGRETS AT THE END OF THE DAY”. Source : From a monthly magazine named “CHANDAMAMA” ( story book for children, most popular in Telugu language ) -These are the facts that I have learnt from my own experience. All type of comments are welcomed!! _M.J

You are worth $20 billion and on your death bed. You know you will be dying in just a few hours or maybe a day or two at best case. You have barely any energy and know you will be asleep soon. Not in the mood for food or anything after having your surge of energy. Ask yourself this, “Does your 20 billion dollars matter to you now?” Why would money be everything in this case? You will be dead in hours. Everyone will go through this at some point in their lives whether you are broke or worth billions. Money is not everything. Your health comes first. Health also includes happiness. Without this money is actually worthless. People want things that only make them happy. Everyone who wants money thinks it will make them happier. Guess what? Money doesn’t guarantee happiness. It might seem as it does but you will be surprised how quickly it can wear off and backfire. What if you have severe health issues and can’t utilize that money? Then at this point, money becomes worthless. And money cannot totally buy health. It can buy a healthy lifestyle, but can never buy health completely because we all die someday. So no, money is not everything or even close to being everything.

This will be the start of a bunch of dark answers about money, value, and power. None of these will be particularly ethical or idealistic, despite my ‘PhD in Idealism.’ So, no. Life is not about money. Life is about POWER. The glorious rush you experience when you overpower an opponent. The satisfaction of victory. The relief that comes when you know that you are safe. In my mind, there are several aspects of power, first and foremost being money. Money, however, is not the meaning of life. If it were, we would see savage competition, war, and greed on a scale that would be scarcely imaginable to us today. People would work only for profit, becoming at first investment bankers and CEO’s, and then becoming cult leaders, murderers, and dealers. That would be a terrible society, with terrible people.  What a lot of people don’t understand is that power is not intrinsically evil. What makes powerful people evil is the process they go through in pursuit of that power. If you have to “shoot your girlfriend’s or boyfriend’s toe for 100 million dollars” then you’re already prepared to shoot them in the arm, in the chest, and after enough desensitization, in the head. That is what makes people evil. Not all power is evil, but it is pretty evident that power is the goal. Look at Quora, even. People here (including me) write for the accumulation of upvotes, views, and followers, which are all essentially pieces of power. People still write on Quora even though it isn’t monetized. They write for the accumulation of power, and to share their own power in a display of generosity across this platform. Life is about power, as strange and dark as that sounds. In the end, it is you who decide how to use that power. And so, ironically enough, Quora itself is the piece of evidence that drives the point home: Life isn’t all about money. It’s about power.

Not really. Money figures “all over the place” in life, or “all about” it - but it is not the main point - which is more a matter of love, and sex, and food, and shelter. But we have developed means of filling our bellies, building our houses, looking after children in organisations we call families, wherein money is a useful tool to organise the transfer of necessary goods and services - like food, like rental payments, like savings and loans - which is just a cunning plan to move constant efforts backwards or forwards in time so as to save a little over many days/weeks/years and then buy a house, or put down a deposit on a house, and simultaneously take on a debt, and then pay it off over many more years. In this way even a poor man can buy a house. You can look upon money as a catalyst for economic activity, or as a lubricant, where strong metal parts move against each other in a machine and the oil eases minute imperfections and departures from perfect circularity of rotating parts - the economy has to balance the differing times of supply with the mismatched demand - “from each according to his ability” - well, the kulak can only supply corn at the end of the summer, when it has ripened and been harvested - and then this corn has to be transferred to grain stores, whence it can be milled into flour on a 52 week timetable, and then baked into bread daily, before becoming something that can be sold/given/provided/allocated “to each according to his need” - and this progress of energy from grass roots to feeding the hungry is much better co-ordinated by a monetary market than by a series of commissars, telling the farmers how much they have to grow - as though plentiful or poor harvests were the result of loyalty to or betrayal of the Red Tsar ! The love of money is the root of all evil - but the proper use of money is one of the essentials of an efficient market economy: which means NO “Quantitative easing” or similar governmentally arranged theft of the value of money - we need good stable money - alas, we have not got anything better than US Dollars, or Petrodollars - Euros - Pounds Sterling, and similar trashy frauds. This second class (third class ?) money is what we have to make do with - makes life needlesly difficult. But that is the politics we get - presumably it is the politics we deserve. Ooooh dearie me, what a mess we have made.

Money is NOT* everything. I look at it this way; I would rather be healthy with a happy family like, a woman that loves and respects me, kids and grandchildren that are healthy, happy and doing well in their lives and be broke than to be a multimillionaire alone because my family hates me, stuck in a wheelchair or hospital bed with a debilitating disease there is no cure for and could die any day. *But I would enjoy a healthy and happy life even more if I had a house paid off and a monthly income (from retirement income, investments, etc) that allowed me to not only live a normal day to day life without the worry of “Can I afford to buy enough food this month” and enough left over to allow me to do some extras, like take my family on vacation occasionally or help them financially (like when they need buy a house but are a little short). I have a friend that is very opinionated on how “everyone is so materialistic and in to owning big houses and cars, smartphones and video games. I could be happy living in a tent in the woods and growing my own food” That may sound romantic to some but I’ll tell you what, that tent is going to get awfully cold in the winter and hot in the summer. And that food isn’t going to grow well when it is zero degrees out. And with no electricity it’s going to be pretty tough to run a computer to write (her passion) and with no internet access, share those beautiful writings with her network of readers from around the world. People say money is the root of all evil. Well guess what, it takes money to live. No one is going to give you shelter, food, electricity, heat, etc. (the basic essentials of living) for free; you need to pay for those things. Where it is evil is when getting money is the number one driving force in your life and are willing to lie, cheat and steal to get not just what you need to live but to keep getting more and more and more…far more than you would ever need or spend. That is when it is evil.

Not at all Okay, so coming down to the human needs what do we need? FoodSleepSocial recognitionLoveSpiritual fulfilmentFood: you need money for this, more money more access to food and more fulfilment of this desire. Food is all abou money. Agreed. Sleep: Do we have to have money for sleeping many times no but sometimes yes. More money better sleep right? But people with less money also sleep so there is not much of a difference. Social Recognition: Money is directly or indirectly related to your social recognition. But this desire also depends on people's ability. Sometimes in a class smarter person is more recognized that a rich person. Same happens in other aspects of life as well. Sometimes money is important sometimes other things are more important. Love: Do we need money for being loved. Some might say yes because the more money you have the more you are eligible to present gifts or fill monetary needs of others. But is love about this? This is the way of channelising love but actually love means your eager want to be considerate and forgiving and rewarding. You can possess all these qualities even if you have less money. Spiritual fulfilment: How many times you had to pay to worship? Probably not a single time. But you can get more spiritual fulfilment by feeding the poor or donating money to the needy ones. Even for these purposes you don't have to have much money. Life is about money if you assume it that way. Money can make your access to things and services. Recently I have been pondering about this question for an irregular amount of time. As I have grown older, money has become a necessity and it is hard to live without. Nothing in the world comes free and money is something used to quantify or measure your work. Ideally, money should keep people honest and working towards a healthier and bright future. We work hard to achieve a higher standard of living and independence. That is admirable; however, reality is not this way. Those who work the hardest do not get the most profit because those who work the hardest are focused only the task. Those who are focused on making money make the most money because they exploit the hard workers and try to market themselves. These exploiters hire the best workers because that is how or society is structured. In short, I like how money gives structure and measures our contributions in a tangible way. What I do not like about money is how it corrupts and changes people. Money can’t buy genuine friendship and respect; however, it can buy fake friendship and fake respect. Maybe those with greed confuse the facade of respect with genuine respect and believe the only way is to make money. Who knows what other people’s intentions are but I think we all strive for the same common values. While I want to believe in the kindness of humans. I find it hard because history proves otherwise. The stronger party always tries to coerce the weaker party until a tipping point where revolutions and war happen. The dominant part does not share part of his authority for the greater good, he just continues to exploit and make things beneficial for him. That is how modern society came to be. Sadly few of us realize this and just live in an ignorant bubble where all the customs were created to favor the one with power.

Most people do not understand, but money is only a tool, just like a hammer is a tool for the carpenter and a kitchenknife is a tool for the cook. But if the carpenter does not use his hammer, he does not build anything. The tool is useless. And if the cook does not use his kitchenknife to cut the vegetables in the right peaces, he does not cook anything eatable. The tool is useless. —————————————————- The answers have been written for other topics. You have to “translate” it to your question. Not everything is meant for your question. Do yourself a favor, read until the end. “How do I start?” 1. Take care of your physical and psychological health in the first place!! This remark has nothing to do with your question, but is inspired by the fact that health is more important than money. 2. First things first. When your money arrives in your account, you FIRST save money (10%), SECOND reduce debt (10%) and THIRD spend money. Otherwise you will find out that there will be almost never money left to save. Then “forget” (as a matter of speaking) that you have saved. 3. What one have to learn about money is that it is just a tool that need to be used in the proper way. A key is a tool to open the lock that keeps the door shut. Throw it through the window and you will not be able to open the right door, take the right care for it and you will be able to. Money is like the crop of a farmer. 10% of the crop is the basis of the crop of the next year. The rest is to make a living off. The farmer lives for his crop, because his crop gives life to so many people, not for the crop itself, but for what it does to himself and many people. The same with money. A scrooge goes for the money for no other reason than the money. A hard working person goes for the money, because it means a living. 4. Another piece of advice I always give is to buy 1 ounce of PHYSICAL silver each month and keep it until the day you retire. In the long run you will have profits. You will not easily sell the silver for other purposes (very important), so you will have your own retirement capital, even if it is a relatively small sum of money. If you are 20 years of age, you have lived for 240 months and you should have 240 ounces of physical silver. One ounce of silver costs now more or less $20, so you should not feel the buy in your budget, even if you have to buy two ounces for the next 240 months, because you started too late with that idea. 5. Choose also one note or coin, that you never spend when it comes into your hands by accident and in an honest way. “My coins” are pieces of €1 and €2. Put them in a jar and “forget” them for a long period of time. 6. Debt and alcohol works in the same way. Use both with moderation and you have pleasure. Enjoy too much and you have problems. Get addicted and you are in real trouble.. 7. Cut up your credit card and use a debit card instead. As far as I can know it is not that simple in the USA because of the laws about improper charges and fraud. 8. Avoid advertising. What ever they told you, the only purpose of advertising is to seduce you to spend your money on their stuff that you nine out of ten do not need anyway. I have a television that can stop and delay the broadcast. I stop at the beginning of the advertising and 7 minutes later I wind fast forward. Window shopping is also a form of advertising 9. 80% of all problems are caused by 20% of reasons. So if you can find out those 20% reasons that make you spend 80% of all your money, it makes easier for you to reduce your expenses. 10. Avoid bars, restaurants and paid entertainment. 11. A penny saved is a penny earned. Many, if not most spending vs. saving decisions occur in the small moments of life, at the pennies level. 12. Create a mantra in the sense of: “Financial succesful people save 10% of there income, are debt poor and enjoy live with the rest of there income.” Say this a thousend times to yourself every day and after many months your unconscious will believe this mantra and start help you to make come true that mantra. Do say “Succesful people do …”, not “I have to do …” because the latter give to much resistance of your unconscious. ——————————————- If you think only in terms of saving money, this could happen to your money. In the 1970’s there was a soap that was called “the six million dollar man”. It was a astronaut that had a terrible accident, but with the help of advanced technology and loads of money, he was rebuild and changed in a superstrong man that worked for the government. What I want to say is that six million dollar was in those days an astronomic high number, a bit like six billion is today. Now it is “just” a big number. Inflation can “eat” away your purchasing power. ——————————————— My way of paying of debt is the 1%-method. I advise you to use 10% of your income for debt repayment. However one want to feel a result almost directly after pay off a sum of money. This is the way one can do it. month 1: $1000 debt. Pay off 1% or $10. month 2 : $990 debt. Pay off 1% or $9.90. month 3: $980.10 debt. Pay off 1% or 9.80 month 4: $970.3 debt. Pay off 1% or 9.7 and your new debt amount is $960.6 Now you will “feel” your effort of paying off debt two ways. You pay back every month a little less and you pay less interest every month. You can play with that 1%-roule. You can make it 5% every month or 0.5%. I gave you an example of what is possible. But make sure that every month the debt is smaller than the month before with at least the percentage you have chosen. ———————————————- “How to invest?” There are two ways. Rental real estate and a combination from precious metals and stocks.Real Estate: Buy a small house or a garage with morgage. Rent it to someone (a garage ask less maintenance) Pay off the morgage with the rent and sell it. ———————————————— When playing the game Monopoly there is almost always a player who chooses to stay on his money in the beginning. At first it seems like a nice strategy. Every time when 'Start' is passed, this player sees his capital grow. This strategy goes well until others start buying houses and hotels. All of a sudden, rent must be paid everywhere. For the player who stayed on his money, the inevitable bankruptcy does not follow much later. In real life it is not entirely true that a person ultimately owns everything, and all others do nothing at all. But in real life too it is true that those who invest their money in assets that raise money themselves (shares for example) are ultimately far better off than those who stay on their money and do not invest. How do you win? How do you win with Monopoly? Buy as many properties as possible. And preferably the orange and red streets because they have the highest expected return. Well considered are the value shares of the Monopoly game! And nice to know: the very most expensive streets - Kalverstraat and Leidschestraat - do not turn out to be such attractive streets to buy. Compare them with the most beloved shares of the moment, the expected return is actually not good at all. The game Monopoly can not be compared completely to real life, of course. But in real life there is certainly a strategy to become rich: 1) Always live below your means, so that there is money to invest; 2) Invest the saved money in assets that raise money yourself. As with Monopoly, it is virtually impossible in real life to save yourself richly. In contrary, it is virtually impossible not to become rich when, for a few decades, both items are held above. From 1979 until 1999 I use USD ($). Later on I use EUR (€) Up to you to use your currency or to pretend that €1 equals $1. This will not infuence the overall result of the study.   Even in this exceptionally bad situation one hits finally profits. One should not be too worried about the value of ones silver investment in the long run if one buy every month 1 or more ounce(s) of silver. ————————————- This is an investment idea. Money ain't everything but you know it helps for building happiness which is something, and because of this point. You can say that it is everything, but do remember the legends like Michael Joseph Jackson who recieved 23 Guinness World records and 13 Grammys, he had so many servants to take care and look after him but still “Death” shook hand with him. Steve Jobs who died at 56 and here is his words when he was going through it. “ I reached the pinnacle of success in the business world. In others’ eyes, my life is an epitome of success. However, aside from work, I have little joy. In the end, wealth is only a fact of life that I am accustomed to. At this moment, lying on the sick bed and recalling my whole life, I realize that all the recognition and wealth that I took so much pride in, have paled and become meaningless in the face of impending death. In the darkness, I look at the green lights from the life supporting machines and hear the humming mechanical sounds, I can feel the breath of god of death drawing closer… Now I know, when we have accumulated sufficient wealth to last our lifetime, we should pursue other matters that are unrelated to wealth… Should be something that is more important: Perhaps relationships, perhaps art, perhaps a dream from younger days … Non-stop pursuing of wealth will only turn a person into a twisted being, just like me. God gave us the senses to let us feel the love in everyone’s heart, not the illusions brought about by wealth. The wealth I have won in my life I cannot bring with me. What I can bring is only the memories precipitated by love. That’s the true riches which will follow you, accompany you, giving you strength and light to go on. Love can travel a thousand miles. Life has no limit. Go where you want to go. Reach the height you want to reach. It is all in your heart and in your hands. What is the most expensive bed in the world? – “Sick bed” … You can employ someone to drive the car for you, make money for you but you cannot have someone to bear the sickness for you. Material things lost can be found. But there is one thing that can never be found when it is lost – “Life”. When a person goes into the operating room, he will realize that there is one book that he has yet to finish reading – “Book of Healthy Life”. This is worth reading. And you touching your parents feet can give them something which money can't.

The school used to end at 5 PM, and most of the parents used to come directly from office to pick their children up. But as you are never sure about the office hours, many parents used to get late. Some would show up at 5:30 while some might get late by an hour too. The school staff was getting tired of this as they were getting late because of such late parents. They had to find a solution. Well, they thought that it is all about money. Let’s charge those parents for being late. So they came up with this notice and sent it to all parents: The school rates punctuality the most. And the same should be followed by parents too. If any parent reaches late to pick up their children, they will have to pay for the delay. The charges would be 100 INR per thirty minutes. The school was happy about this proposition. Now, they were sure that no parent will reach late as all love their money a lot. Next day, they saw a decrease in number of parents coming late. They got happy that it was working. For a week, they could see the change. But, after a week, everything backfired. More and more parents started coming late. Those who used to come by 6 were now coming as late as 6:30 PM. And that idea that they had brought in to make parents come early was now making those parents reach late. When asked why they were coming late now, a parent replied: “Initially, when I used to get late, I felt embarrassed. So somehow I was trying to reach with the least delay. But now since the school came up with the policy of 100 INR per half hour of delay, I got free of that embarrassment. So whenever I have more work, I just try to finish it and then reach school and pay the extra charge.” Is it all about money? You got the answer. Those school staff who tried to enforce fine, the parents were actually happy paying the same. Initially, they were coming on time for saving themselves from embarrassment, but now they had money to spare them from it. -Arjuna@War

Everything, no. The most important thing? Probably. Look at me: I hate money. I hate to think about it, deal with it, having to find ways to earn it. I think that there is so much more to life than a job you don’t like, trying to get ends meet or worrying about riches (or lack thereof). Money in itself is vain, and working to acquiring it without any other consideration is unfulfilling and dull. What’s everything? Time. Time spent to do things you love, helping people you care about, being with your family and working on meaningful projects. And hopefully maxing out on health and longevity to keep doing the above as much as you can before the Universe shuts it all down. That’s why money is so important. Money equals time. Time equals freedom. Money enables you not to care about it anymore so you can focus on what matters most.

Let me ask you a question and you will find out the answer to yours! “What are the five most important things in your life?” (Okay, tell me in the order of their importance) So, anyone like you and me would not take even a second to respond to this question and would present a list which looks something like this:  Yes! And many of us would alter this list and add things like love, happiness, travel etc etc to this. But, to what extent? So, if we were to answer this question, the answer would be something like this:  Okay, true enough. So, if I were to sum it up, I can say that if you have these five things in life, you have 99% of what you want from your life. If these five elements are present in your life, you do not need anything else (all major needs get fulfilled here). Now coming back to your question “Is money the main thing in life?” If you analyze the above five things, you would find that money is not the main thing in life. It will always be a step behind family, friends or maybe it can be ahead all of them in case of a few people. Even if it becomes the main thing in your life, can it help you fulfill all the needs which are important for you? Can it buy you love? Or happiness? It cannot. Money, surely is a part of our life, but it is not the soul of our life. Let me extend my answer. You have everything that is depicted in the bottom layer and those elements have taken you to the next level in your life wherein you have love, happiness, a sense of security etc. etc. But, still there must be something, there must be a reason why you are bothered a lot, why you need to ask on quora whether money is the main thing in life or whether true love exists or not, or any other thing which bothers us and makes us question life. There exists a reason behind this. There is one more level in the pyramid where we haven’t reached yet. Once we reach there, we can travel across the two layers easily without being affected emotionally or mentally. It will enable you to travel down your memory lane, will make you strong enough to face severe financial crisis, it will enable you to face heartbreaks, all because you would know it is the main thing in your life, it is the thing you need to achieve before your death, and not after it.

When I was a school going toddler, my mum brought me a compass box. All the things in that compass box insanely fascinated me. But there laid an eraser in one corner of the box; looking at me with its intent gaze; imploring me with an unshakable attention. I fell for the pleasant smell of the new, young, soft eraser. I didn’t want to lose it at any cost. So, I used it in a careful and thrifty manner. If someone would ask me to lend my eraser, instead of the new one, I would lend him/her an older one. As time sped by, the eraser dwindled in its size - slightly bigger than the size of my nostril. And one fine day, while playing with that eraser over my face, I took a deep inhaling breath, powerful enough to capture the same eraser. It blocked my little passage of breath. I was writhing in agony; trying hard to get that fucking little ball off my nose. But all my efforts in vain. Finally, a nearby doctor removed the eraser with the help of a forceps.  Money holds the same place in life like an eraser holds in a compass box. It’s required to erase discomforts but doesn’t justify our existence. It’s required to make a living, but its overwhelming obsession will lead to suffering. Money is supposed to give us dignity, but with that money, we should be able to give dignity to others too.

Well, what is money? Is money the paper? Is money the ink? Is money the fragrance of money? Money is not what it is but what it does. What does money do? A little bit of honest thinking, reveals the true answer… Money amplifies personal freedom. The more money you have, the more things you can do that you wouldn’t be able to do without money. Here are a few examples, just for fun: You can travel to a new country and experience a different culture.You can enroll in an expensive university and work towards a Masters Degree on a topic you want to become an expert in, so that you can then teach it.You can spend a year in a luxurious cruise ship. You can explore the Mediterranean, Carribean or some other cruisable (new word) part of the world.You can hire the best trainers to help you undo the effects of the sedentary lifestyle, and improve your body and health.You can hire the best psychologists to help you unblock those blockages that drain your energy and prevent you from living life to the fullest, and from reaching your full potential.You can donate a big chuck of it to a cause that you feel strongly about and leave your legacy in that cause. It can be cleaning up plastic in the ocean, saving trees in Borneo, securing the future of an endangered species or feeding hungry children.So the moral of the story is this. Life without money may be better than money without life. But having them both, and having them in abundance, is best. So life is all about money as much as money is all about life. And that’s the Yin and Yang of it. Dictated using SpeechToText Pro.

My heart wants to say No, but my Brain keeps on nagging me to say Yes. So I’ll compromise and say both “Yes” and “No”. You most definitely have heard the phrase “Money doesn’t bring happiness”. And you may have heard that extremely wealthy people often find themselves in depression even though they have everything they’ve ever wanted. Here’s what I’ve learned by reading Epicures’ writings on conquering fear. The human nature is to pursue happiness. Which means that you will do anything you can to be happy, that’s why dopamine inducing substances are so addictive. For example, you like drinking alcohol because it helps the brain release dopamine, you can easily get addicted to Nicotine because of dopamine, so on and so on. But what role does money play in all this? You see, Money is the enabler, it is the gateway to our happiness as some may think. It will just allow you to get the things you want or think you want. So, in this case, I am saying No, it’s not about money, it’s about looking past it and seeing what you truly want. Now I’m going to say that Yes, it is about money. You see just as Epicures says in his book. In order to pursue our happiness, we need to conquer our fears. Now in the ancient times, the fear was of gods, death and many other unrelated things. But today, fears have become more financial. You’re always afraid to buy something when you’re being sold to, even if you want it, you're always afraid to treat yourself to a nice dinner because rent is due to be paid next week. All of these fears combine in each other and tell you that, in order to be truly happy, you need more money. And it is true. Tell me, how easy would it be for you to pursue your dreams, hobbies and things you like if you never had to worry about money ever again? What state would your mind be in when you don’t look at the price tag anymore? When you can just get what you want? It would be a lot more relaxed right? You’ll be able to defeat your materialistic needs and move to more important, spiritualistic ones. This is where people find the largest problems. They can’t figure out what they truly want, now that they have the means to get it. This is the part where they get lost and fall into depression. However, if you have your priorities set straight Money can be your means to happiness, but not happiness itself. Hope you got something out of my answer and sorry if I made it too philosophical.

Once upon a time, the so called Money never existed but still human beings were existing on this earth. This clearly shows that, people could live their life without money. Over the years, the money came into existence replacing the old barter system. I still remember that may be some 30 years back, people in villages used barter system and they never used money. I myself had bought ice cream by giving jawar and wheat during my child hood days in village. Money became much more significant all across this world due to westernization and urbanization. When people started getting more money, they started becoming more greedy to earn more money and money started ruling this world. The problem with money is,” the more you earn, the more you want to earn” Even though every one of us know that, we may need X amount of money to live our life, we always want to accumulate 10X or 100X amount of money. The more money we have, the more happy and secure we feel. Even though money is not everything, but we have created a world which runs only with a fuel called money. We created a system of monthly bills which have to be paid every month irrespective of whether you have money or not. We need money to sneeze and cough. We need money for everything, because this is how we created our living revolving around money. Money is not everything if We invest in Good health than Health InsuranceDon’t get into heavy loans (Housing and Car loan etc)Don’t need luxury lifeDon’t have too many monthly commitmentsDon’t send our kids to expensive schoolsDon’t have too many dependents in family andlast but not the least, we believe in simple living.

Money’s Just a Tool  Similar to a hammer, pencil or axe, money is just a tool that enables you to build what you want. For some people they use it as a tool to build a business, for others its a tool that allows them to build a life of luxury. At the end of the day it inherently has no value or morality attached to it; in most cases its probably just a number in a computer somewhere. It’s how you use it that determines what it’s worth. Freedom isn’t Free With that out of the way I will say that money is a large part of what life is about. Try explaining to a homeless person or a single mother with a ton of bills to pay that money isn’t important; odds are they’ll curse up a storm. Money is important because it gives you freedom. It allows you to live the life you want to live in the way you want to live it. The reason most people go to jobs is so that they can have money to do what they want. If there was an unlimited amount of cash available to people you best believe that we would see quite a surge in the number of people choosing maybe to be a artist or farmer or musician vs sitting in an office all day. When your finances are secure you don’t have to worry about being told to be at a certain place at a certain time, you buy back your freedom and the ability to live how you want. You can spend time with your kids watching them grow up without being away 8 hours a day, travel with your family all over the world, rest in peace knowing that their needs and health are secure in the event of an emergency. Money is the tool that offers these opportunities. Summary: No, it’s not what life’s about, but if you don’t have it don’t expect it to be easy to build the life you want

Whether I think money is everything or not depends on my situation. Had I been a poor peasant who barely earns enough to feed himself and I needed money for the operation of my sick child, then money would be very close to everything for me. My primary lookout would be for money. If I were a person who earns enough to meet his family's daily requirements and also saves some extra money then I would value other things more than money but still it would be very important. As a rich businessman, money would be of less importance to me. I would realise that life can be troublesome even after having lots of money. Other aspects of life would haunt me more in this situation. In short, money is not everything but very close to it for someone who has less of it. With more money, you realise that money can buy happiness only upto a certain extent.

It all depends on what you consider by ‘’everything’’. My personal opinion on the topic is that money, fully, completely, undoubtedly, definitely, surely, unquestionably, certainly, truly is not everything. To think something is ‘’everything’’ it has to do everything with every aspect of your life. What does the love have to do with the money? I guess you are getting my point by now. Stop making excuses for not having money. Stop blaming the lack of money for the failures in your life. Being money-oriented is only a matter of choice. You don’t need a fortune to start a business. You need a real desire, a dream, and a willpower. You don’t need money to get lost. Make your own private isle in the bedroom and shut your brain off for a few moments. Love is not related to money in any way. It never was and will never be. Stop believing otherwise. You don’t need money to save your company. What you need is resourcefulness, consistency and most important – an idea. You don’t need money to have fun. You can have fun while playing twister with your loved ones. You don’t need money to help someone – share your warm meal with them. You certainly don’t have to buy them a new one. You don’t need money to enjoy life. You can do it in your backyard while watching the night sky. You don’t need money to gain respect. It can be done by always being your true self and not giving a damn what other people think. You will soon realize how much people actually appreciate authenticity. All of the things I mentioned don’t require money yet all of them are essential to life. And life itself is our ‘’everything’’. Equation solved.
