It is true that money is everything? Yes and no. Maslow’s hierarchy of needs postulates that there are basic and advanced needs. The two most basic levels, Physiological and Safety, depend heavily on having enough money to purchase them. Anyone who doesn’t feel like those two levels of needs are met will say that money means everything — because for them, it does. Once a person is secure in having those needs met, money is less of a determining value. For the next two levels, Love/Belonging and Esteem, money can play a factor. But not necessarily a determining factor, as this article may explain: How much money you need to be happy varies wildly depending on where in America you live For the top of Masolw’s pyramid, Self-actualization (or Self-transcendence), money may not be an issue at all. But to be sure, anyone who isn’t having their more basic needs met won’t have the energy to work on this level for long.

Obviously NOT. If money was everything in life, the rich would have been the happiest people in the world. That’s not the case. Money is only a means of satisfying your material needs. Many people equate money and wealth as the most important achievement in life. But the satisfaction that you achieve after earning money and accumulating wealth is temporary and not long lasting. People sometimes equate money with power and position in society. This feeling also is always short-lived. With passage of time they want to achieve more wealth, power and position to compete with others. They get into a cycle of setting targets, achieving them and setting yet higher targets. In pursuit of getting more and more, you tend to lose sight of the real purpose of life. There is a lot more in life than satisfaction of your material needs. For your life to be worthy and meaningful, you need to: -Have a good Work Life Balance. Engage in activities which you love and do it to the best of your ability. -Build Strong relationships. Have a good social life and a feeling of being wanted. -Achieve positivity, emotional balance, contentment and peace of mind in life. -Make your life fruitful by doing something which contributes to society.

There are three compartment of social system, A) ComplexityB) SimplicityC) Unity May be I was fortunate enough to see the A and B. Those who don't have resources (here count Money for instance) in the social system almost, all the time try to be either Complex or Simple.  Beings, who don't have good exposure, will turn to be complex. Politicians to Beggars to any Teacher, who may have seen only one dimension, would tend to live complexity.  Belief system, moral codes, expressions, needs and then Liveliness, Jubilant, Moments of life. Perhaps, every aspect of human culture seem a bit tweaked to them.  Same goes well with the people who have seen simplicity of social system. Again, politicians, beggars to any teacher, who may have seen only one dimension, here the simple one, would tend to live simplicity. Liveliness, Jubilant, Moments of life and then belief system, morals, expressions and needs would come to psychology to them. So it's like both the parties, who sees Complex and who sees Simple, are on the same track but at the opposite and. Now, what resources do to their part of life system is, it will pump in the transformation from one side to the opposite. So, if you're into A, you would try to be more simpler in life orientation and if you are in B, you would try to be more complex in the life orientation. Why and How, are different parcels which I don't want to open here. And then there is C. These are the ones, who can be A or B at the time, when needed. They see the real utility of resources. So, money or any other resource per-se, is the instrument to be in the system and be effective to your selection towards A or B. And if you ask to A or B that money is everything, they'll say yes and if to C, they'll say yes/no but only when transformation is needed for their survival. Hope you get it ! ThanksTake care !

No, I don’t. Yet I’m sure 99% people will agree to the fact that money can buy happiness. I’m not an exception either though. But “happiness” isn’t as simple as it seems to be. Psychologists have discovered that there are essentially 2 types of happiness, Extrinsic and Intrinsic. Extrinsic, focuses on money/material wealth, image and status. Happiness derived from these external sources result in a short-lived dopamine spurt and a never-ending state of wanting more. Intrinsic happiness on the other hand is derived from following a passion, personal growth, making the world a better place or loving relationships with family and friends. These are things that money can’t buy, and result in a long lasting joy from within. Yup, it’s true that money is really the thing that matters the most for all of us, however money isn’t ALL that matters in life. Everything else that exists in this world has a purpose too.

Yes and no! Money is everything when you need something tangible. Money also provides you respect, position, and power if you work hard and earn it in the right way. We should not envy those who are rich. Being rich is a privilege and there’s nothing amazing about poverty. Also, many people climb up the ladder in their lives to get a lifestyle they deserve toiling their sweat, tears, and blood. For those, who take birth in rich families, doesn’t necessarily make them worthless. There are many who continue working hard and make judicious use of their wealth. They would love to keep the legacy going forward. Not everyone blows up their acquired wealth. However, we already know that money can’t provide intangible things like emotions, love, a good upbringing, and mental happiness. But being rich is a good feel, especially when you are all deserving and have earned for it.

Not at all. Money is nothing unless it can be exchanged for something that is needed or wanted. All that money is good for is to act as a medium of exchange. If there is nothing buy or sell then all the money in the world won’t keep you alive. Som paper/plastic money might keep you warm for a while if you can burn it, but there again, the fumes from the plastic might kill you. Unfortunately, in today’s world, “money” has become an essential tool for the survival of virtually everyone, but it is only as useful for the things it can buy. There are a lot of other things in life that people need besides “money” - things that “money” can’t buy. Things like genuine friendship, companionship, integrity, honesty and helping other people when they need help. The catch is, to enjoy the things money can’t buy one must be able to stay alive and to do that one must have access to money. Sad but true.

I do not consider money to be everything in my life but we need money to survive in society. In ancient times there was barter system.  People would do what they are good at. They would then exchange what they need with what they have done/created. Now we have money.  You and me get paid for works that we do. Many of us can no longer do, what we might have enjoyed doing, to make our living. Money is the new motivation (there are exceptions though). It works like the key to every kind of material pleasures/desires/wishes. Many people have already changed their passion/interest/hobby to money making systems. While some people are ready to do anything to make money. And almost every living person today needs money to fulfil their pleasures/desires/wishes. I am not trying to judge monetary system, neither am I trying to show that barter system was better or whatever. I am trying to point out that there are many financially backward people on this planet who sacrificed their passion/interest/hobby to make living, and to fulfil their pleasures/desires/wishes. Our priorities have shifted.

Of course not. Money was created as a means of exchange. Somehow, people started using money as a means of power and social status. In other words, the more money you have, the more important you are. Of course this is a bunch of BS. We have all hear it before as people are trying to keep up with the Jones. Money is definitely not everything in life, but a person should never feel guilty about working hard and becoming successful. You need money to take care of yourself and your family. Some lazy people with no drive in life will sit around and talk about how money is not everything in life and put down those who work hard and achieve financial success. Likewise, there are those with lots of money who will put down those who do not earn much money. To sum it up, people are people and money is not everything. It does not buy happiness, but a person should always have an ambition to work hard and take care of themselves and their family. A strong ambition will almost always bring in the money which gives a person more opportunities to travel, buy things they like and to do other things that they enjoy in life. I grew up in a family with not much money in a very bad neighborhood and I now make over $200,000 per year. I will tell you this, I really enjoy providing my family with the things that my parents could not afford when I was a kid. It is nice not having to worry about if my paycheck is going to go on the rent, food or light bill. That is a feeling I will never want to experience again.

As mentioned in the question “small world” ,I will try my level best to justify my answer below. There are few stages of life which everyone has to cross: Stage 1: CHILDHOOD (5–12 yrs)phase where in most of us are fortunate enough to have a family where dad(90% of the times) takes the responsibility of paying our bills (school fees,tuition fees and many more ). That time we are supposed to only study and play/music/dance etc.There we cannot tell that life runs just on money but it is a period to get ready to discover the real self. Stage 2: Teenage (13–19 yrs) phase where in one gets exposed to a different set of emotions ,society and mates.This is where one thinks that life is colorful and have guts to face anything but in most cases we do something to please somebody else and dream of future (thinking money is the only solution for every problem or happiness). Stage 3: YOUTH(20–28 yrs) phase where in everything comes in live and every moment striving to reach peaks in career.Constantly working to get lots of money.This is the moment where you are in the bar with your friends and ready to pay the bill(nobody wants to miss this chance in life right!!!). In this phase TIME = MONEY. Stage 4: MIDDLE AGE(29–40 yrs) phase where we try to settle down and take up responsibilities where again money is involved in everything.Here we plan for future #of the family. Here MONEY =SAVINGS. Stage 5: SECOND INNINGS (sweet 16 & 30+ yrs experience) This is the phase where we have our dream retirement and have nothing to do much#not really ,sitting in the lawn having a cup of tea reading the newspaper and rewinding life (at this stage we just need memories with loved ones not bank balance #that’s true). SO GIVE IMPORTANCE TO MONEY WHEN IT NEEDS AND DEFINITELY MAKE YOUR SECOND INNINGS THE MOST BEAUTIFUL FEELING.

Literally everything? Hard to imagine a black hole or planet made of money. Figuratively everything? Still no, but damned near close. Let me put it this way, if we didn’t have money, we’d need to invent it. Money doesn’t have value. Human labor (time) and property have value. Fact is, you value a great many things. You wouldn’t want to just give those away. When you have a thing (time and/or property), you deserve to have an equitable exchange of those things for the time and/or property of other people. Money allows that to happen by acting as a metaphorical capacitor to store that value until you can find the thing you want to exchange that value for.

No , money is not everything. You cannot buy love. You cannot buy health. Money is useless when you have a life threatening disease or had a life altering accident. You can’t get certain things back. You can’t get time back. Imagine working countless hours for a million dollars a year , only thing is that you have to do it until your newborn child becomes a young adult. You are now disconnected from your child, which would suck. I recently read a story about a person who was pretty much raised by maids because his parents were never home. Although money is important it is not everything. -Brian Grimaldo

Question: Is money everything in life? Answer: Money is a means to an end. Money is a claim toward the society’s goods and services. So money only has value if the society you live in are producing the goods and services that you need and want.Otherwise, it is just a worthless piece of paper / metal / bits in a computer. Assuming you are living in a society that is producing the goods and services that you want, then yes, money is everything. It keeps the roof over your head on rainy and hot daysIt keeps food in the fridge for you and your familyIt gives you freedom to the degree of the safety net (savings and investments) that you can accumulate, so you are not stuck doing something you don’t like just to keep roof over your head and food in your belly.It gives you peace of mindIt pays for your hospital bills when you or your loved ones have accidentIt allows you to go on holiday from time to time and see the worldIt allows you and your children to have good education which helps the society as well in producing more goods and servicesOn microeconomics and personal level, Money makes the world go around. (it is a different point of view from Macroeconomics, but my view on that is unorthodox and controversial, so I’ll skip it for now).

In the latter person’s life, he has a fuck ton of money but it doesn’t bring him the peace of mind that is necessary to achieve a state of happiness. In the end, it all comes down to accepting your current position, and working towards a goal larger than yourself. Humans, especially men, are creatures who thrive on a sense of purpose or mission. Money comes as a consequence of pursuing your mission.

If I am correct in understanding you mean to ask, Once my needs and a few greeds are taken care of, do I still need more money? If not then the very identity of the question is wrong, as Yes you do need money to survive and thrive but how much is too much and where does one draw the line. Let me give you an example. Story of a business family and working class family. One manufactures and exports while the other works in a bank. One has a work force of 100, the other is among a lac employees. One rides a high end car, the other rides a simple car, one is always seen travelling abroad, passports filled and attached, well dressed, suave and sophisticated, the other wears simple but clean clothes, has never been abroad, raises three children. Wife is a teacher as well so they have some savings as well. In both their lives - needs are met. All things were going fine until one day this business man lands up at this mans office, may be for a loan. A businessman that he is, he charmed this man away and made it to his home. Once when home, he sometimes offered the kids chocolates they have never seen, on one occasion or the other a bottle of perfume. Something was already happening in this house. The children started to adore this man, who was he, how come we do not have the luxury he has. He was treated like a man of importance and money became the central point in the house. Something that should not have happened. If the central conversation in your house is about money, without being judgemental at all, you know where you are headed. So COMING BACK TO THE STORY, The son graduates, gets a job and wants to start a business. He knows because, “uncle” would help him. He quits his job and gets into business. His life started revolving around money, he day in and day out spoke money, thought money, dreamt money, loved money and nothing else money. The initial days are full of struggle and the very money he was after made him distant from every thing he ever loved, be it parents, friends, music and life overall. Mind you he was not poor but the central theme in life now was money. He became a very boring person who only talks about money and nothing else. I will stop the story here and may be will continue later if you want to know what eventually happened. But I hope u get the idea, ask yourself If you are the kinds who values people by their bank balance - by all means mate, go for it and build one. If you are the kinds who understands the necessity of it and values other qualities of humans as well then just might have the answer. Its not always about the money.

Money has a bad reputation with people who don't have it. It has been blamed for everything from wars to infidelity, from destroying friendships to wrecking families. In the minds of the masses, the more ways they can demonize money, the more validated they feel for not seeking their own fortunes. Instead of seeing the positive ways that money can enhance the most important things in life like our health, family relationships, and friendships, most people would rather scorn money and tell you how it can destroy the things we hold closest to our hearts. Don't listen to negative people who don't know any better. The truth is money is not the most important thing in life, but it will make the most important things in life so much better. Health A pervasive belief of the masses is that building a fortune requires seven-day workweeks, losing sleep and constant stress. If I believe I have to choose between being rich and being healthy, why would I want to get rich? The truth is wealth gives you far better access to world-class healthcare, preventive medicine, and alternative treatments. If you need a specific cutting-edge procedure that's not available where you live, you simply fly to a place that offers it. Another reason being rich makes you healthier is the elimination of the biggest stressor of the masses: money. The wealthy don't have sleepless nights worrying about paying their bills. Imagine how much healthier you would be if you didn't have to worry about money? How much healthier would you be if you never had to wake up to another alarm clock and could sleep as long as you wanted every day? What would be the impact on your stress level if you could afford to fire your boss? Being rich can positively impact your health. Wealthy people can choose to spend more time with your family.Sean Gallup / Getty Images Family The most common middle-class belief I have encountered is the mistaken idea that you have to choose between world-class success and a happy family life. The masses have been brainwashed to believe it's an either/or equation. This is rooted in a fear and scarcity mentality that says you must choose, because there is only so much time in a day. If you love your family, get rich and give them more of your time, plus opportunities only money can buy. Figure out a way to be more efficient with your time because money can help your family live its dreams. Instead of using your family as an excuse, use them as your primary motivation to start earning more. Don't listen to people who say money leads to dysfunctional families. Dysfunctional families were dysfunctional before money entered the scene; it's just that money magnifies whatever it touches. Money provides the opportunity to make new friends.Dan Kitwood / Getty Images Friends Another common belief that keeps people from getting rich is the idea that they'll lose their best friends if they move into the biggest house on the block. After all, this belief assumes, what good is all the money in the world if you have no friends? It rarely happens. Will you lose a few friends due to jealousy and envy? Maybe. But a better question is: Were they really your friends in the first place? I'm sure you have friends you've known for years, and you could care less about how much money they have. You gain far more friends than you lose when you get wealthy, and I'm not taking about people who befriend you because you're rich. I'm talking about how money opens up the world to you. You'll have the time and resources to travel, meet almost anyone you want, and gain access to the inner circle of some of the most successful, interesting people in the world. Wealth will bring you more opportunity to make friends than anything else in the world. The takeaway It's true, money doesn't buy happiness. But it will make you more comfortable, open doors, create opportunities, and make the good things in your life even better. It may even save your life or the life of a loved one. Decide today to make money a bigger priority in your life. As the late Zig Ziglar said, "Money isn't everything ... but it ranks right up there with oxygen." Steve Siebold is author of "How Rich People Think," and a self-made millionaire who has interviewed more than 1,200 of the world's wealthiest people

Ultimately “of course not only money”, but your personal opinion on this question wil reflect your current state of conscious evolution. Synthesizing insights across several domains of knowledge, there are three broad types of people on Earth: 1. Success oriented: Hawkins Level of Consciousness 0-199; react to life events; philosophy mastering: Aristotle’s virtue ethics. E.g. Donald Trump. 2. Success + happiness oriented: Hawkins Level of Consciousness 199-349; anticipate life events; philosophy mastering: Aristotle’s virtue ethics + Bentham’s consequentialism. E.g. Barack Obama. 3. Success + happiness + peace oriented: Hawkins Level of Consciousness 350-499; shape life events; philosophy mastering: Aristotle’s virtue ethics + Bentham’s consequentialism + Kant’s deontology. E.g. Abraham Lincoln. So if you happen to think that money - and it’s close partner success - are the be all and end all, then: a) You are most likely in current possession of a Hawkins Level of Consciousness from 0-199. b) You are going to get an almighty shcok once you hit Hawkins Level of Consciousness 200 and realise that your journey of life is only just beginning.

What if a that mother gets money from somewhere to feed her children at home, money than become everything . Imagine the scenario no. 2, If a person having lots of money and cars and bungalow but doesn’t have anybody to come at home who is not getting paid , doesn’t have any good friends who play with him just to enjoy his company rather than having some set hidden plans, Money for him seems to be nothing.. Summary: Money is both everything and nothing, It depends on your longings. What you long for in the current moment gives you the answer of this question.

Let's invoke Mathematics for this answer. Assume:  Money is everything in life. Let A = Set of Everything in Life, or the Universal SetA' = Nothing or Null Set Now, by the assumption, Money = A. Then No Money =  A', or nothing. Since there exists at least one thing that you got without money (the most universal example: oxygen), it means that A' is not a null set. This implies that A cannot be a Universal Set.This contradicts our initial assumption. Hence proved. Money is not everything in life. Simple, isn't it?

In the capitalistic society that we live in today, money is what defines our lives. From clothing to food to shelter, an adequate possession of basic necessities requires money. On top of this, individuals must pay for insurance, taxes, education, and other copious expenses. Without it, it would be extremely difficult to survive. While many fail to realize that money simply cannot buy happiness or health, they are blinded by their thirst for power and wealth. Nevertheless, this desire is what motivates people to work and has ultimately lead to the growth of human civilization. With money, people feel a sense of authority and are able to satisfy their materialistic needs. Many equate money to success and will stop at nothing to get it, even if it means doing so at the expense of others. As it is extremely valuable, in the eyes of modern society, money determines an individual’s social status and future success.

Honestly, in the long run, I would say yes. Some people may disagree. I grew up fairly poor, but my mum sent me to a very expensive private school (we got a huge discount since she was a single mother), and even though she did put food on the table, and provide me with everything I needed, she did struggle a lot. She often skipped meals for herself just so she could feed me, and never bought things for herself. She worked 3 jobs just to pay my school fees. She started slowly saving up more and getting back on her feet financially. In 2 years time, she was back on track, and when I went to university (about 5 years after she was quite poor) she payed my university fees all by herself, with money to spare. All I’m trying to say is, money does NOT define who you are as a person, or how happy you will be, but if you work hard, and earn your money honestly, it is one less stress off your shoulders.

Is money everything or no? No, money is not everything. However, money is a universally recognized tool that is used to trade your time, skills, and knowledge for another person’s. (What???) You sell your time to your employer, and then use the money they give you to purchase items that were made by other companies. And, what does that have to do with the question? Well, think about life in general. You need to eat, so you could grow your own food, and harvest your own meat. Or, you could pay someone to do it for you, most likely a lot more efficiently. And, you have a family of some kind, and you want to support the ones you love. Hugs and time together are great, but they also need to eat, a place to live, medical care, and an occasional luxury is not too much to ask for. Right? Easiest way to provide those things are through the use of money. It is true that money cannot buy you happiness, but if you want the luxury of spending time with your family and doing the things you enjoy, you have to sell your time to your employer to afford those things.

When I wasn’t making over six figures, money was everything to me. I had problems making ends meet and everything revolved around these notes. After I started making a great living, money is the last thing I’m concerned about. It’s more of a management task now.

Of course not, but it plays a very important role. The socially acceptable norm is to pretend we should not care much about money. But not caring about money is impractical, irresponsible and hypocritical. The truth is we should care a lot about money as it plays a very important role in our lives. Money helps us cover our basic needs. Money allows us to live well when we age. Money is an enabler for experiences. Money allows people to give children a good and healthy life. Time is infinitely more important than money. However, to enjoy time in your own terms we need money (some of us more, some of us less). Otherwise you will drain your arcs and need to work again to - guess what - building your money reserves. It is important to build wealth, invest it wisely, and have a diversified and passive income. Having said all this, it is important to know how much is enough. Building wealth for the sake of building wealth will not add much value to someone’s life. Build wealth to live, do not live to build wealth.

Not exactly. Saying life is about money is like saying The Titanic is about a ship. The ship is the medium. The movie is about young love and the length one goes to keep it. But it would still be about where you go, what you do, and the company you bring.

Sri Sukadeva Goswami said, "Money does not stay in one place. It passes from one hand to another. Ultimately no one can enjoy money, and it remains the property of the Supreme Personality of Godhead." (Srimad-Bhagavatam 5.14.24) Money is God's energy. He created it, He owns it, and He controls it: "Everything animate or inanimate that is within the universe is controlled and owned by the Lord." (Ishopanishad 1). Krishna determines how much money each of us receives. It may appear accidental that one person is born into wealth and another into poverty, or that one person goes from rags to riches and another doesn't, but Krishna's law of karma destines these things. Srila Prabhupada says, "Everyone is thinking, 'If I become greedy, I shall get more.' That is not possible. You cannot get a farthing more than what you are destined." (Lecture, October 3, 1973) And he writes, "It is not possible that simply by endeavors to accumulate more money a person will be able to do so, otherwise almost everyone would be on the same level of wealth. In reality everyone is earning and acquiring according to his predestined karma." (Srimad-Bhagavatam 3.27.8, Purport) Modern civilization runs on the mistaken concept that if we work harder we will get more money and since money enables us to buy things that please us, with more money we will be happier. Happiness, however, is different from the sensual pleasures money buys. That is why almost all of us are restless and dissatisfied, despite earning and spending vast amounts of money and despite using and owning any number of things. Money does not necessarily produce happiness. Failing to notice this stark truth, many of us pursue happiness by pursuing money. Most people are not satisfied with just enough money to maintain their families but want more and more of it. Srimad-Bhagavatam (4.22.33) tells us, "For human society, constantly thinking of how to earn money and apply it for sense gratification brings about the destruction of everyone's interests." In our mixed-up age, wealth alone is the sign of success and the harbinger of prestige and influence, regardless of one's behavior and qualities. Money and Our Dark Side When we think that happiness would come if we could just afford to make certain material arrangements and adjustments, greed overtakes us. Krishna says that greed is one of the three gates to hell, the other two being lust and anger. We think, "So much wealth do I have today, and I will gain more according to my schemes. So much is mine now, and it will increase in the future, more and more." (Bhagavad-gita 16.13) The lure of money even induces us to forsake our friends and relatives. Srila Prabhupada writes, "Sometimes, being in need of money, the conditioned soul steals and cheats, although he may apparently be associated with devotees for spiritual advancement" (Srimad-Bhagavatam 5.14, Summary) and, "if one person cheats another by a farthing or less, they become enemies." (Srimad-Bhagavatam 5.14.26) Slaves of the pushes of our senses and the quest for money, we burn in an unquenchable fire of our own desires; thus the quality of our life diminishes, and we suffer. Srila Prabhupada writes: "Unlawfully accumulated money is now being snatched from miserly citizens by various methods of state taxation for the future civil and international war fund, which is spending money in a wasteful and destructive manner. The citizens are no longer satisfied with just enough money to maintain a family nicely and cultivate spiritual knowledge, both of which are essential in human life. Now everyone wants money unlimitedly to satisfy insatiable desires. In proportion to the people's unlawful desires, their accumulated money is taken away by the agents of illusory energy in the shape of medical practitioners, lawyers, tax collectors, societies, constitutions, so-called holy men, famines, earthquakes, and many similar calamities. . . . Indeed, that is the law of nature; if money is not devoted to the service of the Lord, it must be spent as spoiled energy in the form of legal problems or diseases. Foolish people do not have the eyes to see such facts; therefore the laws of the Supreme Lord befool them." (Elevation to Krishna Consciousness, Chapter 2) But mundane greed is not intrinsic to us, nor do we naturally exist for the sake of our business and bank balance or to identify with our material accomplishments. Our obsession with money and acquisition is a misplaced religious quest, a religious energy used perversely. The Bright Side Deep inside, we want to complete our term in this world of birth and death, of society and responsibility, of making and doing. We also want to fulfill the incalculably higher and greater possibility offered us as human beings. Each of us senses that we are meant to receive an invaluable gift and to respond with full commitment and service. Lives centered on getting money miss this opportunity and are therefore miserable. But we can use money properly, for the service of its creator, making it a true asset rather than a disguised deficit. Srila Prabhupada writes, "Everything created by the material energy can be dovetailed with the Absolute by an attitude of service, which is the essential part of living energy. The pure devotee of the Lord knows the art of converting everything into its spiritual existence by this service attitude. . . ." (Srimad-Bhagavatam 2.1.20, Purport). The crux of the issue is this: Will I serve the Lord with whatever money He has allotted to me, or will I use it to try to please myself. My consciousness, and not on the amount of money I have, determines my decision. Prabhupada explains: "Materialism does not mean that one has to possess so many things. The actual fact is one may be a perfect transcendentalist or spiritual man by possessing the whole world, and one may be a gross materialist without possessing a farthing. So this distinction can be made on the basis of consciousness. When one is Krishna conscious while possessing everything in the world, he is a perfect spiritualist, and one may have renounced everything in the world, but lacking in Krishna consciousness, he is a gross materialist." (Letter, April 23, 1970) Money and Our Work Vedic society classifies people into four broad groups: brahmanas (teachers), kshatriyas (rulers), vaishyas (farmers and merchants), and shudras (laborers and artisans). Each group relates to money differently. In traditional society the brahmanas accept contributions from their students, but since their material desires are minimal, they keep only as much as they need and give the rest in charity. Brahmanas never hoard money for a luxurious life, as kshatriyas or vaishyas might, but always live austerely, knowing that money easily diverts the mind to materialism. Since kshatriyas rule, they need prestige and money. But their duty-and that of all possessors of wealth-is to give liberally in charity. Vaishyas earn money through agriculture, cow protection, and some trade. By growing food grains and other necessities, vaishyas support themselves and their families without depending on others. Traditionally, shudras are not paid but receive food, shelter, and clothing from the other three classes in exchange for their services. They are well provided for and happy. The term shudra also refers to anyone without spiritual training and knowledge. By that definition, almost everyone today is a shudra, and we see what happens when such people get money: They spend lavishly on sinful activities or accumulate it for no purpose. And they will do almost anything to get more. Money and Life's Stages Srila Prabhupada explains that according to our scriptures, brahmacharis (celibate students), vanaprasthas (retirees), and sannyasis (renounced men) "are allowed to collect alms and are considered as the children of the society, which is composed of householders. In other words, our Vedic civilization is the most perfect community project. Only the grihasthas [householders] are supposed to earn money, especially the kshatriyas and the vaishyas, and the money is distributed community-wide." (Letter, February 11, 1970) In other words, by ruling the citizens or by their business or profession, householders are to earn money honestly and use it to maintain their family and to give in charity to spread Krishna consciousness. In a letter to several householders, Srila Prabhupada wrote, "Krishna will give you intelligence how to engage in honest, brilliant, glorious work on His behalf. There is no need to engage in anything dishonest. Krishna has given enough money, now earn by honest means." (Letter, January 24, 1977) Grihasthas should not slave to accumulate money and unnecessarily increase their material comforts. And if extra money comes, they should use it for Krishna consciousness. To this end, grihasthas may keep their money confidentially so that in time they can spend it for good purposes. There is no fault in this, or in keeping a deposit in the bank for an emergency. Srila Prabhupada once explained how men in Indian villages would live in the city, earn money, and send it back to their family in the village. Their intelligent wives would save that money and eventually invest in land. When they had enough land, the husbands would return to the village and be self-sufficient by producing their necessities from the land. "That's a good idea," Srila Prabhupada said. "Remain in the village with family." (Conversation, January 4, 1977) And he also explained, "The principle is the husband honestly tries to earn livelihood, and at home the wife should be so intelligent that whatever money the husband has earned, she'll manage. She'll not demand, 'Bring money, bring money, bring money . . .' Then the home will be happy." (Conversation, June 14, 1976) The main point is that everyone must learn to spend money only for good causes. Money and Krishna's Service Householder devotees are obliged to earn money because without money it is not possible to exist in the material world. In Chaitanya-charitamrita (Madhya-lila 16.238), Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu tells Raghunatha, "You should not make yourself a showbottle devotee and become a false renunciant. For the time being, enjoy the material world in a befitting way and do not become attached to it." In other words, householders do not give up earning money, but while earning, they think of Krishna constantly and consider themselves humble servants of society. Householders who know that the Lord owns and controls all money are not diverted by excessively thinking about how to accumulate it. And they use what they have for Him. Srila Prabhupada writes, "If one engages for the service of the Lord whatever money one has honestly earned, that is spiritual service to the Supreme Personality of Godhead, the spiritual master, and the Vaishnavas." (Chaitanya-charitamrita, Antya-lila 6.275, Purport) Devotees live according to their means: "Since a devotee wants to satisfy the desires of the Lord, he can, Lord willing, accept all kinds of opulence for the service of the Lord, and if the Lord is not willing, he should not accept a farthing." (Bhagavad-gita 1.32-35, Purport) Frugality is perfectly acceptable to devotees because they know that their spiritual advancement, and not a large income or showy opulence, pleases their spiritual master. "Why should one be anxious about the necessities of life? The principle should be that one should not want more than what is absolutely necessary. . . . The devotee should always be alert to consume only those things that he absolutely requires and not create unnecessary needs." (Chaitanya-charitamrita, Madhya-lila 24.262, Purport) At the same time, devotees balance their obligations so that they and their relatives are secure: "Srila Rupa Goswami taught us by his own example by using fifty percent of his accumulated wealth for Krishna, twenty-five percent for his own self, and twenty-five percent for the members of his family." (Srimad-Bhagavatam 8.19.37, Purport) But whether one has a lot of money or just a little, inevitably one will be separated from it, through spending or death. As Srila Prabhupada said: "You have to change your body. So you have earned so much millions and billions of money. That's all right. But you have to go empty-handed. The money will remain here. You cannot take that money within the tomb. That is not possible. Then it is zero. You are going empty-handed. You came empty-handed and going empty-handed. You came with zero and you are going with zero. So whatever you have earned, that is zero. But if you have attempted to serve Krishna with all these zeros, then you have taken some value." (Conversation, July 31, 1975) Money Wasted "Whatever money we are getting it is from Krishna," Srila Prabhupada wrote, "so nothing should be misspent." (Letter, October 24, 1974) Earning an income is not difficult because Krishna provides for His sincere devotees. But not misspending the money is difficult and takes intelligence. Krishna provides, and improper spending can be a problem even among exalted devotees. For example, once Chaitanya Mahaprabhu "respectfully told Shivananda Sena, 'Take care of Vasudeva Datta very nicely. Vasudeva Datta is very liberal. Every day, whatever income he receives, he spends. He does not keep any balance. Being a householder, Vasudeva Datta needs to save some money. Because he is not doing so, it is very difficult for him to maintain his family. Please take care of Vasudeva Datta's family affairs. Become his manager and make the proper adjustments.'" (Chaitanya-charitamrita, Madhya-lila 15.93-96) Like Vasudeva Datta, those who lack wisdom in spending should put themselves under the care of a wise, trustworthy devotee. The Favor of the Goddess of Fortune "Everyone is seeking the favor of the goddess of fortune," Srila Prabhupada writes, "but people do not know that Lord Sri Krishna is the beloved husband of all goddesses of fortune." (Srimad-Bhagavatam 2.4.20, Purport) When we try to engage the goddess of fortune in Krishna's service, we gradually realize Him in every sphere of life. By this culture of Krishna consciousness, our happiness will no longer depend on how much money we have. We will be content even without money. "If there is no culture," Srila Prabhupada said, "simply by money you cannot maintain a standard of civilization. That is not possible. Now the American leaders, they are thinking, 'Let us have money, then everything . . .' Of course, by money you are covering all the defects of the social culture. But this will not endure. The day will come when everything will be exposed. Therefore culture is required." (Conversation, June 14, 1976) One who has culture has faith in Krishna, and therefore has everything. Srila Prabhupada writes, "A pure devotee who has firm faith in the words of the Supreme Personality of Godhead is to be considered a most learned scholar, the topmost aristocrat, and the richest man in the whole world." (Chaitanya-charitamrita, Madhya-lila 5.76, Purport) Finally, in Srila Prabhupada's words again: "Guru Maharaja said that 'You do the right work, money will come. Money will fall down on your feet.' There is no question of flattering. Do. Work sincerely. Everything will come, whatever you want." (Conversation June 30, 1977)

Money is the greatest invention of all time. Without money, there would be no specialization of skills, which means we would all be living in grass huts struggling for survival. Imagine the millions of dollars it takes to build a computer factory, for example; it simply wouldn’t be possible with a barter economy. How do you produce a multi-million dollar facility and staff if by trading chickens and goats? It doesn’t work. You need a store of value, i.e. money. Everything awesome on this earth is due to the specialization that money provides. But without love, who cares? So no, money isn’t everything, but having a lot of it sure makes life easier.

Money is nothing by itself. The value of money is determined by what you do with it. Money, by itself, can bring short term happiness, but what good is money, if it isn’t used to better yourself, or others, throughout your life? If money was everything, or rather, meant everything, we would not see celebrities and rock stars killing themselves, suffering from addictions to reality escaping drugs, constantly appearing in rehab, and seeking psychological help for massive breakdowns. Family, love, and personal accomplishment trump money by far. At the end of your life, will the most important thing you reflect on is the pieces of green paper you have stored up in a brick institution? It’s everything to those that don’t have *any* of it, but it is meaningless in the hands of someone that doesn’t have “life.”

Going to keep this short… Is it everything? No…yet money is still very important to a certain extent. While health and love are more valuable, money often plays a factor. Think about it. If you want to be healthy, you need to live on a diet filled with protein paired with fruits and veggies rather than living off of nothing but peanut butter sandwiches 24/7. Want love and friendship? Even money has an influence in this area. I know it might sound cruel and shallow, but you’ll be more likely approached when you look good, which means nice clothes, a great haircut, and good hygiene—it does cost money to take a shower and brush your teeth! You also need enough money to have a social life. It can sure put a strain on friendships when you’re too broke to go out to movies, restaurants, or even entertain at home due to a lack of food! Basically, while you don’t need to live an elite lifestyle, it’s important to have enough to live in comfort. Better to be crying in a Honda Fit than on a public bus!

In the first world, absolutely. It is nearly impossible to live a social life in a first world country without money. It doesn’t have to be a lot of money, but you’ve got to have some money to interact with others. In some third world societies, money is not used in any form. So for them, no. But what is money? Money is an concrete representation of an abstraction - how much value you (or your parents) are to society. I would like to answer this because 15 months ago I went from a six figure salary to $0-. The answer is still a definitive no. What money gives you is options. Certainly having options can make your life easier - but easier may not necessarily equate to happier - and it certainly does not give you everything. Think of it like this - If you are hanging for a Pizza - and you can get one, you have satisfied the most pressing desire you had. The Pizza only cost you a couple of dollars. There are plenty of other better, more nutricious and tasty cuisine available and you probably could have afforded them - but Pizza was on your mind. So too, money is like that. I have had virtually no money for 14 months but the priorities in my life have not changed from when I had money. For that matter, nor has access to money directly changed the priorities. When comfortable, the “everythings” to me were the care and respect of my daughter, the love and happiness of my girlfriend, the well-being of my family and friends, my own sanity, courage and self-belief. I only have a certain degree of control and influence over all of these things - and money certainly will not determine these things on its own.

You ask whether or not money is everything in this world. Well, the phrase sounds familiar, since the larger percentage of folks seem to adhere to that dictum. Yet, even love’ so to speak can be bought viz. prostution et al. - as everyone knows! But what is the difference between buying or obtaining something in exchange for money, and achievimg something through ‘love’ which we may translate into devotion, worship, caring, compassion and indeed acts of self-sacrifice for the benefit of the world. Money does not ‘buy’ these latter rubrics, yet they may be fuelled by so called money. I need to drive to the lecture hall where folks are gathered to hear kathaa…hence gas is needed. You need to buy books for your illiterate students so they may benefit from the medium supplied . Hence money used in the service of the divine becomes Laxmi! And that Laxmi is but the spiritual Partner so to speak, of the Supreme One in Charge. Hence everything dedicated in the service of the Supreme, takes on the hue of Sublimity! Thus money can serve in the matter of acts of charity and love, indeed acts of self-sacrifice for the purpose of anugraha , blessings for the entire world! Om Tat Sat: peace for all!

To know the answer read the whole story below carefully. I live in a small town in U.P and belongs to a middle class family. There is a broken old building near our house. The owner of this building lives in foreign (may be in Canada , don't know exactly). In this old building, every summer an old aged man in his 60s setup his swing boat (like shown in below image) and a trampoline there and charges Rs. 5( may be more now but when I was a kid he charged Rs.2 for 10 min of ride. So I'm assuming to be Rs.5 now. )  [Image source: GOOGLE] Few kids go there for ride and he manages to afford his two square meal only with his earning. I usually see him from my window and he seems happy all the time singing classic bollywood songs on top of his voice while giving children rides . He has no advance gadgets and facilities, He has a basic keypad phone and a radio which he listen to till 12 in the night. Me too cheers his song in the night and nobody in my house has problem with it because these old songs work as lullabies for us and we sleep peacefully. He lives in a tent as this old building has no roof. He cooks for himself on a fireplace made by him with bricks and I can bet he is an amazing cook as the smell of his cooked gravy makes me go crazy !! He has left this place 2 days before and I am missing his presence, his lulliabies and delicious smell of his cooked gravy :( I will see him in next summer. This is the image of the old building without him  [Image source: Phone gallery] I have learn a great lesson of my life just because of him . I have seen many people (including us) richer than him but no one looks more satisfied and happy than him with their life. Everyone has their own goal and after achieving that they aim for another goal and this goes on and on unending and in this process we forget to be happy and satisfied with our life. We don't cheer little things around us , we focus more on things which we don't have instead of focusing on what we have and how we can enjoy them to the fullest. We are strongly manipulated by our surrounding, social media, t.v serials, online advertisements every second in believing that the one with branded clothes, expensive phone and cars are happy with their life and that is the point where we get trap and start struggling to be happy. “You’re not your job, you’re not the car you drive, you’re not the contents of your wallet” - Tyler Durden So, is money everything for life ? DEFINITELY “NO ”

Money is not everything in life. It’s what you do with money that gives it purpose, value and significance. If you use it for a good cause and that gives you a sustainable sense of fulfillment, money will be an asset. However if you use money meaninglessly and worst, it generates negative outcomes and results, money becomes a liability. Other than money, there are other important and perhaps even more important values such as love, gratefulness, family, friendship, and giving back to society. Make money your servant for worthwhile causes and not your master and you’ll be on the way to a greater sense of happiness and fulfillment.

Money can buy most things but it is not everything. Money cannot buy friendships and relationships (the genuine ones); money cannot buy peace of mind, money cannot buy real happiness and money cannot buy principles.  There are very rich people who are often miserable, and there are many poor people who are happy and contented.  When used for material satisfaction and selfish purposes, the 'joy' money brings is superficial and temporary but if used for the good of all, money can bring real joy to both giver and receipient.  So, money is good and money is useful but money is not everything.

Original question was: “Is money the main thing in life?” No! However, I can only answer for myself: Live your life in selfless pursuit of the happiness and welfare of your friends, family, and loved ones. Do this without expectation of a return in kind, and happiness for you comes. Forget this rule and you eventually come to regret it. By the way, both Plato and Aristotle pointed out that “happiness” (meaning in their language eudaemonia, which is “contentment” or “inner peace”) is the only thing we do in life that is not done for the sake of something else, and is therefore the ultimate goal of life. Money is important in the same way air, food, and water, is important. You need it to live comfortably according to your standard of living. Beyond that, it has no value.
